results.title: Did a Neanderthal Who Lived 43,000 Years Ago Paint a Red Nose on a Rock That Looked Like a Face?
results.description: Based on the placement of the red dot, they theorize that the Neanderthal thought the stone looked like a face and wanted to complete the resemblance. They suspect the individual was experiencing pareidolia, a phenomenon in which the brain perceives patterns and images—often faces—in inanimate ...

results.title: Neanderthal - Wikipedia
results.description: His grandfather, a musician, had changed the family name from the original German Neumann ("new man") to the Graeco-Roman form Neander, following the fashion of the time. Neanderthal can be pronounced using the /t/ (as in /niˈændərtɑːl/) or the standard English pronunciation of th with ...

results.title: Did a Neanderthal Spot a Face in This Rock 43,000 Years Ago—and Leave a Fingerprint Behind?
results.description: Forensic police experts then used multispectral analysis—a technique that can reveal details invisible to the naked eye—to confirm that the red dot had been applied with a fingertip. Their analysis uncovered a fingerprint that could have belonged to an adult male Neanderthal inside the dot.

results.title: Scientists injected 40,000-year-old Neanderthal DNA into mice, resulting in very unexpected changes
results.description: Researchers insert a 40,000-year-old Neanderthal variant of the GLI3 gene into mice, altering their bone structure without malformations.

results.title: Ten Ancient Secrets from the Neanderthal World - Listverse
results.description: An ancient fingerprint found on a rock in Spain suggests the Neanderthals may have created art. Researchers believe an archaic man dipped one of his fingers in red pigment and used it to mark his pebble canvas. The stone looks a bit like a human face with a red, painted nose.

results.title: Neanderthal extinction - Wikipedia
results.description: Indirect dating of Neanderthals remains from Mezmaiskaya Cave reported a date of about 30,000 years ago, but direct dating instead yielded 39,700 ±1,100 years ago, more in line with trends exhibited in the rest of Europe. The earliest indication of Upper Palaeolithic modern human immigration into Europe is a series of modern human teeth with Neronian industry stone tools found at Mandrin ...

results.title: Ancient fingerprint in Spain may offer new insights into Neanderthal psyche
results.description: It was imprinted on a granite pebble the researchers nicknamed "Perico." The stone drew attention not only for its ochre markings—a natural clay-based pigment used by Neanderthals—but also for natural grooves that resembled a human face, a phenomenon known as pareidolia.

results.title: Homo neanderthalensis - Wikipedia
results.description: Uno studio del 2014 sul DNA di una donna di Neanderthal, i cui resti sono stati ritorvati nella grotta di Denisova in Russia, dimostra che i suoi genitori erano imparentati al livello di fratellastri, e che l'accoppiamento tra parenti stretti era comune tra i suoi antenati più recenti. Considerando che la maggior parte dei manufatti ...
